importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when a fraudulent call from a fake Defence Minister Guido Crosetto was reported, marking the beginning of a major AI voice scam targeting Italian businessmen.
The date when Defence Minister Guido Crosetto publicly disclosed receiving a call from a purported friend, revealing the AI-generated scam and prompting public awareness.
The start of a growing trend in deepfake scams, with global losses rising from $200 million in Q1 to $347 million in Q2 of 2025.
The date when US President Donald Trump signed a federal law criminalizing the publication of AI-generated intimate images of individuals without consent.
The date when Resemble AI released a report showing over $547 million lost globally to deepfake scams between January and June 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from January to June 2025 saw a significant rise in global deepfake scams, with losses exceeding $547 million, indicating a growing threat of AI-powered fraud.
By the end of 2025, DeepMedia estimates that around 8 million deepfakes will have been created and shared online, a dramatic increase from 500,000 in 2023.

keyTakeAways: AI-generated voices are now indistinguishable from real human voices, especially when trained on deep learning models using real voice data.
AI voice cloning is being used in sophisticated scams, such as fake calls from government officials like Italy’s Defence Minister Guido Crosetto, asking for money.

A study by Queen Mary University of London found that 41% of AI-generated voices and 58% of voice clones were mistaken for real human voices, and participants often rated AI voices as more trustworthy.
Deepfake audio and video are being used to create fake news, manipulate public opinion, and generate illegal content, including AI-generated child sexual abuse material.
The US and Australia have introduced legal measures to criminalize the distribution of AI-generated intimate images, highlighting the global concern over misuse.
Despite risks, AI-generated voices have beneficial applications, such as helping individuals who have lost the ability to speak to regain a personal voice.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A growing number of AI-generated voice scams are targeting wealthy individuals, using deepfake technology to clone real voices—such as that of Italy’s Defence Minister Guido Crosetto—to solicit large financial transfers. The scam, which occurred in early 2025, involved fraudulent calls from fake government officials asking for money, with only one businessman, Massimo Moratti, transferring funds. Research from Queen Mary University of London shows that AI-generated voices are now nearly indistinguishable from real human voices and are often rated as more trustworthy. Global losses from such scams have surged to over $547 million between January and June 2025. The technology also enables the creation of fake videos and illegal content, including AI-generated child sexual abuse material. In response, governments like the US and Australia have introduced laws criminalizing the distribution of AI-generated intimate images, highlighting the urgent need for public awareness, legal reform, and technological safeguards.
title: AI now sounds more like us – should we be concerned?
